bug.short_desc: iOS: Native scrolling via -webkit-overflow-scrolling: touch; CSS slows down if Touch handler was loaded

long_desc.thetext:
Using native scrolling for div's of iOS is more scale-able. The performance is very fast. But our touch event handler slows it down.
Point on a scrollable div and scroll up and down. In a profiler you can see a massive call of event dispatcher. This seems to decrease the acceleration. Because if you disable touch event handler manually, scrolling runs perfectly, even with a huge amount on child elements in the scroll container.
We should try to find a generic way to prevent firing touch-move events on scrolling natively.

(In reply to comment #0) > We should try to find a generic way to prevent firing touch-move events on > scrolling natively.
As there is no build in support for native touch scrolling, I can't think of a generic solution to that as far as I understand the idea. Could you be a bit mor precise about how you think that could work?
